metadata.title: ALS Caregiver's Compass - Comprehensive FAQ
metadata.description: Practical wisdom from 650+ Indian ALS caregiving families - the insights doctors don't tell you
metadata.source: ALS Care & Support India Community + Medical Sources

core_principles.title: A Note on Positivity and Practicality
core_principles.description: Being positive is good for both PALS and CALS. It helps us stay strong and hopeful. But at the same time, at least one family member should stay practical when it comes to making important decisions. As PALS and CALS, we often feel that we will beat this disease. We don't want to think negatively. We feel we will never need BiPAP, PEG tube, or any supportive devices. But sometimes, too much positivity keeps us in a kind of delusion. We also worry that if we start using supportive devices, we will become dependent on them and destroy our body's natural capacity. This thinking is correct to some extent. But it can also make us delay important decisions and miss the right time to act. In ALS, we should not overexert the body. Using support devices like BiPAP, wheelchair, and feeding tubes actually helps reduce muscle fatigue and preserves strength for longer.

core_principles.title: The Reverse Principle
core_principles.description: In ALS, using support does NOT make you dependent. It's the REVERSE. The less fatigue we give to the body, the better we are dealing with MND/ALS. Early support PRESERVES strength.

core_principles.title: Being Practical vs Being Positive
core_principles.description: It is good to stay positive and hope your PALS may never need BiPAP or feeding tube. But sometimes this positivity becomes a delusion, and we avoid being practical. No doctor will tell you 'now is the right time' - YOU as CALS need to be practical and recognize the signs.

core_principles.title: The CO‚ÇÇ Problem - Why SpO‚ÇÇ is Misleading
core_principles.description: In ALS, the problem is NOT getting oxygen in - it's getting CO‚ÇÇ out. Weakened diaphragm muscles prevent proper exhalation. SpO‚ÇÇ readings can be misleading because CO‚ÇÇ retention doesn't show up initially. Your PALS can have SpO‚ÇÇ at 96% and still desperately need BiPAP.

core_principles.title: The Hindsight Perspective
core_principles.description: Those whose PALS are already on BiPAP and feeding tubes see the WHOLE picture. They wish they had started earlier. They see how early use could have prevented emergencies, preserved more muscle strength, and given more quality time.

key_principles: Early BiPAP can delay tracheostomy by 6 months to 2+ years
Early PEG prevents emergency situations where both PEG and tracheostomy are needed together
Normal SpO‚ÇÇ readings can hide dangerous CO‚ÇÇ buildup in ALS patients
No doctor will tell you 'now is the right time' - you must recognize the signs yourself
In ALS, less fatigue = slower progression. Using support is smart, not giving up
Emergency interventions are traumatic and riskier than planned ones - anticipate, don't react
You know your PALS best - trust your observations
Using support devices helps preserve strength, not weaken it
Plan ahead rather than react to emergencies
Every PALS journey is different - take guidance but make decisions right for your situation

questions.question: When does a PALS need BiPAP and how to decide?
questions.answer:
Understanding the Core Problem

In ALS, the problem is NOT getting oxygen in - it's getting CO‚ÇÇ out. The diaphragm muscles weaken and cannot push air out properly, causing CO‚ÇÇ to get trapped. This is why SpO‚ÇÇ readings can be misleading - your oximeter can show normal (96-98%) while CO‚ÇÇ is building up to dangerous levels.

What is BiPAP?

BiPAP (Bilevel Positive Airway Pressure) is a non-invasive ventilator that helps breathing by providing two pressure levels: higher for inhalation (IPAP) and lower for exhalation (EPAP). It helps push CO‚ÇÇ out and gives rest to tired breathing muscles.

Signs That Indicate BiPAP is Needed

Look for these signs, even if SpO‚ÇÇ looks normal:

  1. Difficulty sleeping flat - needs 2-3 pillows or recliner
  2. Morning headaches - indicates CO‚ÇÇ buildup overnight
  3. High pulse rate (100+) even with normal SpO‚ÇÇ - body working hard to breathe
  4. Excessive daytime drowsiness - tired even after sleeping
  5. Breathlessness while eating or talking
  6. SpO‚ÇÇ dropping during deep sleep - check at night, not just daytime
  7. Cannot sleep at night / frequent position changes - Waking up, turning sides many times
  8. Respiratory rate higher than 25 breaths per minute
SignsAction
Cannot lie flat, needs pillows or reclinerAct immediately
Waking up with headachesAct immediately
SpO‚ÇÇ dropping below 94%Act immediately
Breathlessness at rest or while talkingAct immediately
Increased fatigue, daytime sleepinessMonitor closely, prepare BiPAP
Disturbed sleep, gaspingMonitor closely, prepare BiPAP
SpO‚ÇÇ below 95% during sleepMonitor closely, prepare BiPAP
Important: If you see any 2-3 of these signs, discuss BiPAP with your doctor and experienced CALS immediately.

The Mindset Shift Needed

Think of BiPAP as a tool for quality of life, not a sign of defeat:

  • Early use = preserved muscle strength
  • Early use = fewer emergencies
  • Early use = more good days
  • Early use = can delay tracheostomy by 6 months to 2+ years
Important: Everyone with ALS should be prepared with BiPAP regardless of whether they need it now or not. No one knows when the emergency arrives. Keep BiPAP ready at home BEFORE you need it urgently.

From a CALS Who Learned the Hard Way:

'We didn't have BiPAP at home and rushed to hospital due to emergency - tracheostomy done. If we had started BiPAP when signs appeared, we could have avoided this emergency.'

questions.question: Can early BiPAP help delay tracheostomy?
questions.answer:
YES! Community experience shows that PALS who started BiPAP early were able to delay tracheostomy by 6 months to 2+ years in many cases. Some PALS have continued on BiPAP for years without needing tracheostomy.

How Early BiPAP Helps

  • BiPAP gives the diaphragm muscles 'rest' by helping with breathing
  • Less muscle fatigue means slower deterioration
  • Emergency situations are prevented
  • PALS can maintain a better quality of life
Starting BiPAP EarlyWaiting Until Emergency
Start at first warning signsWait thinking 'we'll start when really needed'
Use during sleep initially, gradually increaseMuscles weaken silently over time
Muscles stay stronger for longerSudden respiratory crisis
Can delay tracheostomy by months to yearsMay need emergency tracheostomy
Family has time to prepare and learnEmergency decisions, less preparation time
If tracheostomy eventually needed, it's plannedUnplanned tracheostomy in ICU
Remember: Using BiPAP is not 'giving up' ‚Äî it's being smart about preserving muscle strength and energy, and avoiding emergencies. The less fatigue we give to the body, the better we manage ALS.

questions.question: What is the difference between Oxygen and BiPAP?
questions.answer:
This is a very important distinction. Many families think oxygen and BiPAP are similar or interchangeable. They are not.

The Key Difference

FeatureOxygen OnlyBiPAP
Increases oxygen in blood‚úÖ Yes‚úÖ Yes
Helps remove CO‚ÇÇ from body‚ùå No‚úÖ Yes
Supports weak breathing muscles‚ùå No‚úÖ Yes
Safe for ALS when used alone‚ö†Ô∏è Can be risky‚úÖ Recommended

Why Oxygen Alone Can Be Dangerous in ALS

In ALS, the main problem is that weak muscles cannot push CO‚ÇÇ out. If you give only oxygen:

  • The SpO‚ÇÇ reading looks good (95%+)
  • Family thinks everything is fine
  • But CO‚ÇÇ keeps building up silently
  • CO‚ÇÇ buildup causes confusion, headaches, and eventually crisis
  • The oxygen gave a false sense of security

This is why BiPAP is almost always better for ALS patients with breathing difficulty. BiPAP helps push air in AND helps push CO‚ÇÇ out. It supports the tired diaphragm muscles.

Rule of Thumb: For ALS/MND with breathing difficulty, BiPAP is almost always better than oxygen alone. Consult a pulmonologist familiar with ALS.

questions.question: When Is Tracheostomy Needed? What are the decision criteria?
questions.answer:
Tracheostomy is a significant decision. Community experience shows it is needed in two scenarios:

Scenario 1: Planned Tracheostomy (Preferred)

This is when you have time to prepare and plan properly. Tracheostomy becomes necessary when ALL of these are true:

  • PALS is 24x7 dependent on BiPAP (not just nighttime use)
  • The normal airway (nose/throat) has become too weak
  • PALS is unable to maintain SpO‚ÇÇ even with BiPAP (SpO‚ÇÇ dropping below 90)
  • ABG (Arterial Blood Gas) shows high CO‚ÇÇ despite BiPAP support
  • Unable to clear secretions from lungs, leading to frequent chest congestion and infections

Scenario 2: Emergency Tracheostomy

This happens when there is no time to plan:

  • PALS gets pneumonia that is not properly managed
  • There is a sudden drop in oxygen saturation due to severe infection
  • There is no time ‚Äî doctors must intubate and perform emergency tracheostomy

How to Understand Your Situation

IF...THEN...
PALS uses BiPAP only at night and maintains good SpO‚ÇÇ during dayContinue monitoring. Tracheostomy is not needed yet. Many PALS continue this way for years.
PALS requires BiPAP 24x7 and still struggling to maintain SpO‚ÇÇThis is the time to act. Plan tracheostomy proactively.
Frequent pneumonia and BiPAP becoming insufficientUrgent discussion needed. Don't wait for emergency.
PALS already intubated in ICUTracheostomy is usually the safest option after intubation.
Important: Tracheostomy is not an easy decision. Understand the requirements, process, and future care protocol. Discuss with family members and experienced CALS before deciding.

if_then.if: PALS uses BiPAP only at night + maintains good SpO‚ÇÇ during day
if_then.then: Continue monitoring ‚Äî not ready for tracheostomy yet

if_then.if: PALS requires BiPAP 24x7 + still struggling to maintain SpO‚ÇÇ
if_then.then: This is your time to act ‚Äî plan tracheostomy proactively
Urgent discussion needed ‚Äî don't wait for emergency
Tracheostomy is safest option after intubation

questions.warning: PLANNED tracheostomy is ALWAYS better than EMERGENCY tracheostomy. Emergency situations lead to trauma, longer ICU stays, and worse outcomes.
questions.recommendation: For tracheostomy, talk to experienced members of the ALSCAS group, talk to as many caregivers as you want. Decision should be yours, your family's, and PALS's together.
perspectives: Tracheostomy need arises when PALS become 24x7 dependent on BiPAP, the normal airway has become weaker, plus they are unable to maintain saturation even with BiPAP ‚Äî then tracheostomy is a must.
Many PALS continue on NIV BiPAP for years with good secretion management and cough assist use.

questions.question: How to delay or avoid emergency tracheostomy?
questions.answer:
The goal is to either delay tracheostomy as long as possible, or if it becomes necessary, to have it done in a planned manner rather than an emergency.

Ways to Delay Tracheostomy

  • Use BiPAP early and consistently - This gives rest to breathing muscles and delays the need for tracheostomy by months to years
  • Use Cough Assist machine regularly - This helps clear secretions from lungs and prevents lung infections
  • Get PEG early - This prevents aspiration from oral feeding, which is a major cause of pneumonia
  • Treat respiratory infections aggressively - Don't let a small infection become pneumonia
  • Good secretion management - Regular nebulization, suctioning, and chest physiotherapy

Avoid the Emergency Scenario

  • Keep BiPAP ready before you need it
  • Have cough assist available if possible
  • Act quickly at first signs of infection - don't wait
  • Have a plan with your doctor for what to do in emergencies
  • Consider home ICU setup for managing care at home
The planned approach is always better. It gives time to prepare mentally, financially, and set up proper home care.

questions.question: What are HME filters and why are they important?
questions.answer:
HME (Heat and Moisture Exchanger) filters are important for tracheostomy patients:

  • Warm and moisturize the air entering the lungs
  • Protect from dust and particles
  • Should be changed regularly

When breathing through a tracheostomy, the air bypasses the nose and throat which normally warm and humidify the air. HME filters help replicate this function, keeping the airways moist and protected.

Tip: Keep spare HME filters at home and change them as recommended by your respiratory therapist.

questions.question: When should we consider a feeding tube (PEG)?
questions.answer:
The same logic as BiPAP applies here: early adaptation to feeding support is very important. Don't wait for emergencies.

Signs That It's Time to Discuss Feeding Tube

  • Meal takes too long - If eating a normal meal takes more time
  • Difficulty swallowing - Food feels stuck or hard to swallow
  • Coughing or choking while eating or drinking
  • Fear of eating - PALS avoids food because of choking episodes
  • Weight loss
  • Exhaustion after meals - Eating should not make you tired
  • Repeated aspiration - Food may be going into windpipe which can lead to lung infection and emergency
Delaying PEGEarly PEG
High risk of aspiration pneumoniaLungs are protected
Malnutrition and weaknessNutrition is maintained
Each meal becomes stressfulNutrition without stress
Emergency PEG is riskierPlanned PEG is safer
Weight loss is hard to reverseWeight is maintained

Important Clarification

Having a feeding tube does NOT mean no oral eating:

  • Many PALS continue to eat favorite foods by mouth for pleasure
  • The tube provides nutrition without the stress and aspiration risk
  • It's supplementary support, not a complete replacement
  • PALS can still taste food - just not depend on oral eating for all nutrition
Important: Repeated aspiration causes lung infections. Aspiration pneumonia can lead to emergency. Get PEG done while respiratory function is still reasonable.

questions.question: What Nutrition is Best for ALS?
questions.answer:
Core Principles:

  • High Calorie: Needs are high! Aim for 2000-3000 calories/day to prevent weight loss from muscle wasting.
  • High Protein: Essential for muscle maintenance. Whey protein, paneer, dal, rajma, chana, eggs.
  • Good Fats: Critical for energy. 2 teaspoons of ghee, coconut oil, or olive oil daily is beneficial.
  • Omega-3: Omega-3 oil capsules, flax seeds, chia seeds.

Practical Tips:

  • Consistency: If swallowing is difficult, avoid thin liquids. Use liquid thickener if required.
  • Small frequent meals: If PALS is losing weight or avoiding food because of choking episodes, consider PEG. When PEG starts, PALS starts getting high quality nutrition immediately and it makes a big difference to their health.

questions.question: How to thicken water for PALS with swallowing difficulty (dysphagia)?
questions.answer:
Why Thicken Liquids?

Water and thin liquids can be difficult to control because they move too quickly. For PALS with weakened swallowing muscles, thickened liquids slow down the flow and make swallowing easier and safer, reducing choking and aspiration risk.

When to Start Thickening:

  • Coughing or choking when drinking water
  • Difficulty swallowing liquids

Community-Recommended Thickening Products:

1. Nestle Resource ThickenUp Clear
Clear, dissolves well without lumps, available on Amazon, Flipkart, medical stores.

2. Nature's Velvet Xanthan Gum Powder
Natural thickening agent, cost-effective alternative.

3. Thick-It (Imported) (‚Çπ1,200-1,800)
Well-known international brand, available on Amazon India.

Important: Thickening is a temporary solution - if swallowing worsens, PEG tube is the safer long-term option.
questions.recommendation: Consult a speech therapist to determine the right consistency level for your PALS.

questions.question: Why do families delay BiPAP even after knowing the signs?
questions.answer:
The Positivity Trap

Being positive is important for both PALS and CALS. It gives us strength to fight. But at the same time, at least one family member should stay practical when it comes to making important decisions. It keeps us in a kind of delusion:

  • We truly believe our PALS will never need these devices
  • We think 'let's wait and see how it goes'
  • We see stable SpO‚ÇÇ and think 'everything is fine, no support needed yet'
  • Accepting BiPAP feels like accepting that the disease is progressing
  • We worry that using BiPAP will make PALS dependent and weaken muscles further

This last fear is actually the opposite of reality. In ALS, the less fatigue we give to the body, the better. Using BiPAP gives rest to the diaphragm muscles and actually helps preserve their function for longer.

Waiting for Doctors to Decide

Many families wait for doctors to tell them when to start BiPAP. But there are some challenges:

  • Many doctors, even good ones, may not have extensive experience with ALS
  • They often look mainly at SpO‚ÇÇ levels - if it's above 95%, they may say 'no need for BiPAP'
  • They may miss the importance of symptoms like difficulty sleeping flat or morning headaches
  • They may not check diaphragm muscle strength specifically

Some PALS approach doctors at the right time asking about BiPAP, but the doctor says 'lungs look fine, SpO‚ÇÇ is maintained, no need for anything.' The doctor's answer should ideally include analysis of diaphragm muscle strength, not just lung condition.

What Should CALS Do

Don't overly depend on the doctor to come and tell you 'now start BiPAP.' As CALS, you should:

  • Carefully observe your PALS for the warning signs
  • When in doubt, discuss with experienced CALS who have been through this
  • Think and analyze whether BiPAP is really needed now or can wait
  • Discuss with your doctor, sharing your observations
  • If you feel it is the right time but the doctor is not convinced, seek a second opinion
  • If you are sure it's needed, don't hesitate to get BiPAP and seek help from other doctors or experienced CALS to set it up
Remember: At least one family member should stay practical and take timely decisions, even while everyone stays positive and hopeful.
perspectives: We were on the other side of the picture and made the same mistake. Things look easy when reading these messages, but when you're living it, you're sometimes over-positive.
Those who have seen the other side keep repeating this because they wish someone had told them earlier.

questions.question: How to Deal with Hospital Staff Ignorance?
questions.answer:
The Reality of Care:

Many doctors and nursing staff, outside of specialized neurologists, may lack specific knowledge about ALS/MND care protocols. Hospitals are often understaffed, and standard protocols can sometimes be harmful for ALS patients (e.g., giving high-flow oxygen without BiPAP).

Community Wisdom:

  • Educate Yourself: You must become the expert. Learn from the ALSCAS website and experienced community members.
  • Confront if Needed: Be prepared to politely but firmly question wrong practices (like using CPAP instead of BiPAP).
  • Home is Safe Haven: Bring PALS home as soon as they are stable. Home ICU setups often provide more focused and safer care than general hospital wards.
  • Train Your Team: Don't rely solely on hospital nurses. Train your own home attendants and family members.
Community Insight:
'The neurologists, pulmonologists, ICU doctors do not have knowledge about this disease and they want to just blindly follow protocols. The only way is we need to educate ourselves and confront.'

questions.question: How to manage constipation?
questions.answer:
Constipation is very common in ALS due to reduced mobility, medications, and reduced fiber/fluid intake.

Treatment Based on Severity

SeverityDurationTreatment
Mild1-2 days no stoolHigh fiber, more fluids, Cremaffin, isagbol
Moderate2-3 days no stoolLactulose syrup, Cremalax 5mg, Polyethylene Glycol
Severe3+ days no stoolCremalax 10mg, Suppository, Enema if needed

Polyethylene Glycol (PEG laxative) is highly recommended by community members. It softens stool without causing cramps or diarrhea.

Cremaffin is a gentle option for regular use. Avoid Cremaffin Plus for regular use as it can cause dependency.

Prevention

  • High fiber diet - fruits, vegetables, flax seeds daily
  • Adequate hydration - 1500-2000 ml fluids per day
  • Review medications - Gabapentin, Pregabalin, and painkillers cause constipation
  • Regular meal times
  • Amla juice, Triphala, or Harde as natural options

About Enema

'Enema has its own pros and cons. Pros - immediate relief. Cons - can cause dehydration and sometimes leads to diarrhea.'

Enema gives immediate relief when other methods haven't worked, but use it sparingly. Plain water enema is safer than other types.

questions.question: How to prevent bedsores?
questions.answer:
Prevention is Better Than Cure

Bedsores are much easier to prevent than to treat. Once they develop, they can be very difficult to heal.

Prevention Steps:

  • Air mattress - This is essential. Keep the pump running always.
  • Position change every 2 hours - backcare
  • AbZorb powder on lower back and buttocks - Keeps skin dry
  • Cold-pressed coconut oil - Apply on back and pressure points daily
  • Water cushion bag for tailbone area - Very helpful for sitting
  • Keep skin dry - Moisture promotes sores

Products Commonly Used

  • Air mattress - Romsons or similar (‚Çπ2,000-5,000)
  • AbZorb powder - Available at pharmacies
  • Coconut oil - Cold-pressed is preferred
  • Barrier creams - Zinc oxide based
Important: If a bedsore develops, consult a wound care specialist immediately. Deep bedsores can be very serious and difficult to heal.

questions.question: How to manage drooling / excess saliva?
questions.answer:
Drooling (sialorrhea) is a common symptom in ALS. It is generally not due to overproduction of saliva, but rather difficulty swallowing or clearing the saliva (dysphagia).

Management Strategies

  • Glycopyrrolate - Reduces saliva production (use cautiously, can thicken chest secretions)
  • Hyoscine (Scopolamine) Patch - Applied behind the ear to reduce secretions; less systemic side effects than oral medications
  • Amitriptyline or Atropine Drops (sublingual) - Can be used off-label to reduce secretions
  • Regular Oral Suctioning - Use a portable suction machine for immediate relief, especially before sleeping or speaking
  • Positioning - Sitting up helps saliva drain; tilt the head slightly forward or to the side when resting
  • Power Drool (available from Romsons) - Absorbs drool. Disposable gauze or handkerchiefs can also be used
  • Botox Injections to Salivary Glands - A specialist procedure for severe cases where medication is ineffective. It temporarily paralyzes the major salivary glands
  • Oral Care - Maintain excellent dental hygiene and keep the mouth moist with frequent sips of water (if safe to swallow) or mouth spray to prevent thick, sticky secretions
Tip: Consult your doctor about the best approach for your PALS. Different approaches work for different people.

questions.question: What essential equipment should we have at home as ALS progresses?
questions.answer:
Staged Equipment Guide Based on Community Experience:

üîµ EARLY STAGE Equipment:

  • Mobility aids (walker, walking stick)
  • Shower chair and bathroom grab bars
  • Elevated toilet seat
  • Non-slip mats throughout home
  • Simple home modifications (remove rugs, clear pathways)

üü° MID STAGE Equipment:

  • Wheelchair (manual or electric based on arm strength)
  • Hospital-style bed with adjustable height
  • Portable suction machine (for saliva management)
  • Communication aids (alphabet board, eye gaze device)
  • Air mattress or pressure-relieving mattress

üî¥ ADVANCED STAGE Equipment (Have BEFORE Needed!):

  • BiPAP machine - DON'T WAIT! Get when early signs appear
  • Pulse oximeter - Monitor SpO‚ÇÇ regularly
  • Cough assist machine - Helps clear secretions
  • Feeding tube supplies (if using PEG/Ryles)
  • UPS/Inverter/Generator - CRITICAL for power backup
  • Ambu bag - Manual resuscitation for emergencies

‚ö´ FOR TRACHEOSTOMY CARE:

  • Portable suction machine (MUST have)
  • Tracheostomy supplies (cannulas, dressing)
  • Humidifier for ventilator
  • Backup ventilator circuits

Community Pro Tips:

  1. Power backup is NON-NEGOTIABLE:
    'We almost lost our father during a power cut. Now we have UPS + inverter + generator.'
    Invest in reliable UPS (‚Çπ15,000-30,000 for good quality)
  2. Get BiPAP BEFORE you need it:
    Rental first to try, then buy
    Having it at home reduces emergency hospital visits
  3. Cough assist is underrated:
    'Cough assist machine would have postponed my father's tracheostomy'
    Cost: ‚Çπ1.5-3 lakhs, but worth it
  4. Second suction machine:
    Keep one portable for travel/emergencies
    Always have backup

üáÆüá≥ Budget Considerations:
Start with essentials, add as needed. Many items available on rental (BiPAP, hospital bed). Some NGOs provide equipment support. Second-hand equipment from other CALS families (check groups).
questions.recommendation: Don't wait to buy equipment until emergency. Plan ahead based on progression stage. Rent first, then decide if purchase makes sense.

questions.question: How do I manage if there is a power cut while PALS is on BiPAP or ventilator?
questions.answer:
THIS IS A LIFE-THREATENING SITUATION - Prepare BEFORE It Happens!

Backup LevelEquipmentRun TimeCost (‚Çπ)
Level 1UPS with extra batteries30-60 mins15,000-30,000
Level 2Inverter with batteries3-6 hours25,000-50,000
Level 3Generator (petrol/diesel)Unlimited30,000-80,000

Recommended Setup:

  • UPS for immediate switch (no gap in power)
  • Inverter for medium outages
  • Generator for extended outages
  • ALL THREE if PALS is ventilator-dependent

Emergency Protocol During Power Cut:

  1. First 10 seconds: UPS should auto-switch
  2. Check BiPAP/ventilator is running
  3. If NOT running: Start manual Ambu bag immediately
  4. Within 5 minutes: Start generator if inverter insufficient
  5. Call for help if you cannot manage alone

Manual Ventilation with Ambu Bag:

  • MUST know how to use BEFORE emergency
  • Practice with respiratory therapist
  • Keep Ambu bag near PALS at all times
  • One squeeze = one breath (match normal breathing rate)

Real Stories:

‚ö†Ô∏è 'We almost lost our father during power cut. The inverter wasn't charged. Now we have triple backup.'
‚úÖ 'Every night I check UPS charge level. Peace of mind is priceless.'
‚ö†Ô∏è 'Generator didn't start because we never tested it. Always run your generator once a week!'

Pro Tips:

  • Test all backup equipment WEEKLY
  • Keep generator fuel stocked
  • Have electrician's number handy
  • Inform your electricity board that you have a ventilator patient
  • Some areas give priority power restoration for medical cases

üáÆüá≥ India-Specific:
Electricity boards have provisions for medical cases. Apply for priority power restoration. Some states waive/reduce electricity charges for ventilator patients.
questions.warning: Power backup is CRITICAL. Test regularly. A ventilator patient cannot wait even 2 minutes without power or manual ventilation.

questions.question: How to Set Up a 'Home ICU'?
questions.answer:
Many experienced families find that a well-equipped home is often safer and more comfortable than a hospital.

Essential Equipment

  • Ventilator/BiPAP with backup machine
  • Oxygen concentrator with backup cylinder
  • Suction machine (with battery backup)
  • Cough assist if available
  • Multipara monitor (SpO‚ÇÇ, heart rate, BP)
  • Ambu bag for manual ventilation
  • Hospital bed with adjustable elevation
  • Air mattress

Power Backup

  • UPS dedicated for medical equipment
  • Inverter with tubular batteries
  • Generator for long power cuts

Never rely on just one backup. Have multiple layers.

Medications to Keep at Home

  • Nebulization medicines - Levolin, Mucomix, NS, Budecort
  • Emergency antibiotics - As prescribed by doctor
  • Fever medicines - Paracetamol
  • Constipation medicines - Cremaffin, Lactulose, Suppositories
  • Wound care supplies - Betadine, dressings, ointments

Staffing

  • Trained caregiver/nurse 24x7
  • At least one family member trained in emergency procedures
  • Contact numbers of doctor, ambulance, other CALS for emergencies
Tip: Keep emergency IV antibiotics at home after consulting your doctor. Know when to manage at home vs when to seek hospital help.

questions.question: How do I manage excessive saliva/Drooling?
questions.answer:
Secretion Management - A Daily Challenge for Many CALS:

Why Secretions Increase in ALS:

  • Swallowing muscles weaken
  • Cannot swallow saliva normally
  • Saliva pools in mouth and throat
  • NOT increased saliva production, just reduced clearing

Management Strategies:

1. Positioning:
Keep head slightly elevated. Side-lying position helps drainage. Avoid flat lying (increases pooling).

2. Suctioning:
Portable suction machine (‚Çπ5,000-15,000). Learn proper technique. Change suction machine filter and vacuum set regularly.

3. Medications (Consult Doctor):

  • Glycopyrrolate - Reduces secretions (use cautiously, can thicken chest secretions)
  • Power Drool - Available from Romsons
  • Scopolamine patches (no personal experience)
  • Note: These medications can thicken secretions

4. Botox Injections:
In severe cases, Botox injections to salivary glands can help reduce saliva production. Consult neurologist.

questions.question: Will using a power wheelchair or lift make the PALS weaker faster?
questions.answer:
No. This is a common misconception.

The muscles affected by ALS are already diseased and cannot be strengthened through exercise. Conserving energy by using assistive devices‚Äîsuch as a power wheelchair, mechanical lift, or supportive braces‚Äîactually helps the PALS maintain energy for essential activities like breathing, swallowing, and communicating.

Key Point: Using support devices helps preserve strength, not weaken it. The less fatigue we give to the body, the better.
